Thanks for the info.  I like this approach, because it
still allows us to test protected methods.  I also
like that the test packages are identical to the
production packages.

Does anyone have experience using inner classes and
JUnit in order to test private methods?


--- Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...> wrote:
> I don't want to start another "holy war"...  just
> presenting another POV:
> 
> if your production classes are located unter a src/
> directory, just 
> mirror your hierarchy in a test/ directory.
> 
> you will have then:
> src/edu/washington/library/Book.java
> and your test in  :
> test/edu/washington/library/BookTest.java
> 
> You will be able to test your public interface,
> striped them when 
> dealing with the release but you will be able to:
> - test your protected methods
> - easily generate Javadoc with Ant (as far as I
> know, the Javadoc Ant 
> task can't deal with FileSets, so it's impossible
> (?) to only include 
> your production classes in your javadoc
> documentation)
> 
> You can have a look at some really well organized
> projects (those of 
> Jakarta for example - http://jakarta.apache.org) and
> see by yourself.
> 
> But it's a matter of taste.
> 
> -Vladimir
